report_title: Accommodation and Food Services in the US
executive_summary: The U.S. Accommodation and Food Service industry has undergone a unique transformation in response to technological advancements and changing consumer preferences. The progression from primarily traditional dining and lodging paradigms towards digital marketplace models and experience-based venues is a key trend shaping this sector's recent past and future trajectory.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC LED TO REGULATIONS RESTRICTING TRAVEL AND PUBLIC GATHERINGS
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: These restrictions resulted in an estimated 70.0% of direct hotel employees being laid off or furloughed during the first quarter of 2020, according to the American Hotel and Lodging Association (AHLA).

Disposable income growth has benefited the sector because individuals account for more than 80.0% of the market for sector services. When levels of discretionary income increase, they tend to increase their spending across all aspects of the economy and spend on more expensive and higher-end services.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: CONSUMER PREFERENCES ALSO INFLUENCE DEMAND FOR SECTOR SERVICES
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Consumers have increasingly been drawn to health-conscious eating, niche markets and a la carte services, contributing to a sector-wide shift as food service providers cater to these trends.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: US Economic Growth Will Have a Continued Positive Influence
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The sharp incline in the unemployment rate will reverse, approaching pre-pandemic levels. As consumers have more available income, they will likely spend on sector products and services, choosing to eat out at food service establishments or book travel plans.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: CHANGES IN CONSUMER PREFERENCES WILL INFLUENCE SECTOR GROWTH
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Consumers will become increasingly health conscious, changing demand for sector goods, particularly within the food services subsector. Healthier products have an added cost premium due to the more expensive ingredients and careful preparation, providing increased profitability to restaurants with more health-focused menu offerings.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: TRAVEL TRENDS GREATLY INFLUENCE THE ACCOMMODATION SUBSECTOR
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The strong growth at the beginning of the outlook period results from consumers postponing 2020 travel plans because of travel restrictions during the pandemic. Falling costs of international flights will cause inbound trips by foreign residents to increase, allowing sector service providers to take advantage of the increased level of international tourism.

industry_definition: This sector is primarily occupied with providing lodging and food services to consumers for immediate consumption. This includes hotels, motels and other accommodation formats along with full-service restaurants, limited-service restaurants, food contractors and drinking places. This sector excludes civic and social organizations and entertainment facilities, such as theaters and amusement parks, that provide food services as a secondary product.

negative_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level low - steady

opportunities: High Performance Drivers - Number of households

key_trends: The COVID-19 pandemic was disruptive to the Accommodation and Food Services sector. The pandemic affected not only indoor operations, but also reduced customers' purchasing power for sector services.

Growing customer preferences for healthy and vegetarian food will be more prominent over the next five years. Adult obesity and health consciousness will drive demand for this food, requiring more food service providers to include these items in their menus.

Increasing inflation rates might deter customers from visiting sector establishments because per capita disposable has declined. Income-restricted individuals will opt for home meals and at-home entertainment.

Enterprises in the Accommodation and Food Services sector are governed by a wide range of regulations that vary depending on the function of the individual industry. This sector specializes in many service-based industries subject to federal and state regulations that typically focus on labor, health and other safety concerns.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Households' demand heavily rely on available disposable income
demand_determinants.determinant_description: As individuals have more disposable income, they are more likely to forgo cooking at home, dine out, or take a trip and stay at establishments offering accommodation services.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast region has the largest concentration
The West region has the second-largest concentration of the US population and sector establishments
The Mid-Atlantic region has the third-largest concentration of sector establishments

regulations_points.regulation_description: Many establishments in this sector rely on young and low-skilled workers that work part-time or hourly and are subject to federal and state minimum wage requirements. In 2023, the federal minimum wage is $7.25 per hour. However, different states may have different minimum wage rates.

regulations_points.regulation_title: The Patient Protection Affordable Care Act (PPACA)
regulations_points.regulation_description: PPACA requires establishments with 50 or more employees that work more than 30 hours a week to provide healthcare benefits. As most players employ only part-time workers, this will not majorly affect most industries within this sector.

This organization is responsible for establishing rules and standards for food handling and presentation, including the Food Code, which is updated annually to reflect the current food service environment.
For establishments to serve liquor, they must obtain a license from their state. Some states have stricter requirements and may restrict the number of licenses it distributes.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Capital intensity varies between the different industries within the Accommodation and Food Services sector as each industry is subject to vastly different degrees of capital costs, from significant real estate investments to low-budget food trucks.

basis_points.basis_description: Barriers to entry for most industries in the sector are low, resulting in a highly fragmented landscape. As a result, competition is fierce between establishments in those industries.

basis_points.basis_title: Competition from homemade meals and at-home entertainment
basis_points.basis_description: Besides competing with other sectors, sector service providers contend with homemade meals and at-home entertainment options. This was prevalent during the COVID-19 pandemic and will likely grow when inflation increases.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Vastly diversified product and services offerings
concentration_points.concentration_description: The sector has many enterprises, with just one operator, McDonald's, representing more than 5.0% of the market share.

The industries that make up the sector have varying degrees of market share concentration. The extreme divergence in market concentration among industries stems from the functions and economies of scale within each industry in this sector.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchases are the largest cost for a majority of operators. Purchase costs include goods purchased by businesses that are a necessary part of day-to-day operations. During the pandemic, purchases included additional equipment and furniture to offer outdoor dining.
Wages represent the second-most significant expense for this sector. The sector relies heavily on labor for its day-to-day functions.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Capital intensity varies between the different industries
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Capital intensity varies between the different industries within the Accommodation and Food Services sector as each industry is subject to vastly different degrees of capital costs, from significant real estate investments to low-budget food trucks.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Demand for sector services is primarily driven by overall economic performance. Changes in the unemployment rate, interest rates, consumer spending, corporate profit and other economic indicators influence sector revenue.
International activity, such as exchange rates and political turmoil, can affect revenue volatility as many sector establishments provide services to international tourists.
In particular, the COVID-19 pandemic has led to a sharp decline in travel and consumer spending, primarily attributed to added regulations that limited sector operations.

FAQs.question: Does your company leverage social media platforms like Facebook or Twitter to inform and attract new customers?
FAQs.answer: - Smaller nonemployer operators in this sector leverage social media as an inexpensive marketing tool. - Operators with economies of scale may leverage social media but tend to focus more on commercial advertising. - Companies have increasingly relied on social media to attract customers amid the COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic.

FAQs.question: How do review sites, such as Yelp and Google Reviews, impact sales?
FAQs.answer: - Operators in this sector rely on Yelp and Google Reviews to draw in consumers. - Establishments with higher reviews are likely to draw in new consumers and win back previous consumers.

FAQs.question: Although high-traffic areas can incur higher rent expenses, being located in these areas can attract more customers. Is your company located in high-traffic areas to increase visibility?
FAQs.answer: - Operators in high-traffic areas are more likely to draw in higher volumes of demand due to high visibility. - Establishments that are in more exclusive locations may benefit from limited competition.

FAQs.question: Do you offer ancillary services to diversify revenue streams?
FAQs.answer: Some accommodation providers may offer food services or spa services in an effort to diversify revenue streams. Food service providers may offer a variety of food options throughout the day to increase revenue streams. During the coronavirus pandemic, more restaurants offered takeout and delivery services as restaurant operations were limited.

FAQs.question: Does your company leverage mobile booking applications to streamline the booking process?
FAQs.answer: Large operators in this sector that have economies of scale have increasingly been using mobile applications to create convenience for consumers. These technologies may not be beneficial for smaller sector operators. However, many companies increased use of such applications as the coronavirus pandemic limited use of alternatives.

FAQs.question: Does your establishment offer complimentary Wi-Fi to customers?
FAQs.answer: Some accommodation providers include free Wi-Fi to customers while others make Wi-Fi and a la carte option. Food service providers, particularly cafes, may offer free Wi-Fi to entice consumers who work from home or freelance to do work at their establishments. Many food service establishments have begun providing menus by QR codes, which has supported the need for Wi-Fi for customers to access menus.

FAQs.question: Many accommodation and food service establishments are franchises of major brands. Is your company subject to any franchising laws?
FAQs.answer: - Operators in this sector may choose to franchise their establishments in an effort to take advantage of lower upfront costs and access to established economies of scale. - While larger brands take part in significant franchising activity, this sector has a large number of owner-operated establishments that are not subject to franchising regulation.

FAQs.question: Is your business subject to state laws pertaining to the sale of certain items, such as liquor? Is your business subjected to other state laws, particularly as they pertain to the coronavirus?
FAQs.answer: - Many operators in this sector are subject to liquor sales and licensing laws. - Many states and municipalities have specific regulations surrounding sale and distribution of alcoholic beverages, forcing sector establishments to be aware of specific regulations that impact their operations.

FAQs.question: How does your company compensate for the seasonality of cash flow? How has your company compensated for volatility during the pandemic?
FAQs.answer: During the coronavirus pandemic, food service establishments, in particular, have needed to contend with added government regulations, such as a temporary closure of dine-in services followed by limited indoor and outdoor dining capacity. Providers that are located in seasonally lucrative areas may close down, limit employees and hours of operation during off months. For instance, establishments located near ski resorts experience heightened demand during winter months. Other providers may not be subject to seasonality. Volatile demand and frequent changes in regulations and operational capacity have further contributed to volatility for industry operators.

FAQs.question: Profitability varies by industry within the sector. How does your company's profit compare to your main competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Profit varies greatly among the different industries in this sector. Overall, this sector is subject to high levels of competition which can lead to suppressed profit. The average profit margin, measured as earnings before interest and taxes, for sector operators is expected to be 6.4% in 2021, a notable decline from the start of the period, driven by pandemic-related declines. However, this marks the start of recovery in industry profitability from 4.7% in 2020.

FAQs.question: How do you monitor inventory levels? Do you budget for changes brought on by seasonality?
FAQs.answer: Ability to control stock on hand. Monitoring inventory is important so operators are never short on popular items nor have excess levels of inventory. Food service operators tend to seek seasonal food items that align with local weather conditions, particularly for locally sourced foods.

FAQs.question: How can you maintain a good reputation? Do you encourage patrons to review services on Yelp! or Google Review?
FAQs.answer: Having a good reputation. Maintaining a good market reputation ensures that reviews by travel and food guides will be positive, which will encourage more consumers to dine or stay at sector establishments. A positive reputation encourages customers to return to sector establishments while also attracting new customers.

FAQs.question: How do you attract and retain skilled employees that have undergone training? Are work contracts flexible?
FAQs.answer: Access to multiskilled and flexible workforce. Access to multiskilled and well-trained staff is vital as operators must be able to provide quality service, particularly during peak demand periods.

FAQs.question: How does the number of domestic trips affect demand for your company? What percentage of your revenue comes from domestic travelers?
FAQs.answer: Domestic trips by US residents. Trends in domestic travel and the total nights spent away from home directly affect demand for operators in this sector. As the number of trips made by US residents rises, demand for accommodation and food services increases.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor trends in consumer spending? How does your company fare when consumer spending is low?
FAQs.answer: The Accommodation and Food Services sector is heavily dependent on consumer spending. As individual consumers and household make up more than 80.0% of the market for sector services, operators in this sector benefit when consumer spending increases. Over the five years to 2021, consumer spending has increased, despite some declines during the pandemic.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor the number of households? How does your company mitigate declines when the number of households decline?
FAQs.answer: Number of households. As the number of households increases, spending on services provided by sector establishments is likely to increase. Over the five years to 2021, the number of households has expanded.
